item.title: BC’s $183 Billion Fund Is Ready for Deals After Raising Cash
item.description: British Columbia Investment Management Corp. signed 45 deals during the past six months and sees an opening to do even more as it tries to exploit the uncertainty in financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Layan Odeh

item.title: Trump Says He Thinks Middle East War is 'Over'
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US would hold a meeting with Iran next week, but cast doubt on the need for a diplomatic agreement. Trump claimed that US bombing had "obliterated" Iran's key nuclear sites, including Natanz, Isfahan, and Fordow facilities, and that the country's nuclear materials were buried under "granite, concrete and steel". The US and Iran are set to resume talks, with Trump citing Iran's foreign ministry assessment that its nuclear installations were "badly damaged" by US airstrikes. Bloomberg's Ethan Bronner reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Mars’ $36 Billion Kellanova Deal Hit by Full-Scale EU Probe
item.description: Mars Inc.’s $36 billion bid for Pringles chips maker Kellanova faces a potential glitch after European Union opened an in-depth investigation over concerns the largest packaged-food deal in almost a decade could thwart competition.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton

media:content.media:description: Packages of Pringles chips, manufactured by Kellanova.

item.title: Italy’s Serie A Considers Stake Sale in Overseas Media Rights
item.description: Italy’s top football league is exploring selling a stake in its international media rights business, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Barbaglia, Daniele Lepido, David Hellier

media:content.media:description: The Serie A Enilive logo

item.title: FedEx Warns of Tariff Pain as Trump's 90 Day Pause Nears End
item.description: FedEx Corp. forecast a worse-than-expected profit for the current quarter and said it would only share its outlook for the current quarter due to the uncertain environment for global demand.FedEx cites the impact of President Donald Trump's trade war and soft demand as reasons for the decline, with US-China shipments deteriorating sharply in May and expected to remain under pressure. Bloomberg Intelligence's Lee Klaskow reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: One Sign That US Economic Exceptionalism Is Dead
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: A shopper pushes a cart with cardboard boxes outside a Home Depot store in Roseville, California, US, on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025. Home Depot Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on February 25. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: S&P 500 Wavers Near Peak as Buyer Fatigue Kicks In: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s torrid rebound from April’s meltdown is showing some signs of exhaustion on speculation stocks have run too far amid economic and geopolitical risks. Short-dated Treasuries outperformed. The dollar fluctuated. Oil bounced from the biggest two-day decline since 2022.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated to lawmakers that the central bank is in no rush to lower interest rates while waiting for more clarity on the economic impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs. “For the time being, we are well positioned to wait to learn more about the likely course of the economy before considering any adjustments to our policy stance,” Powell said Tuesday in remarks before the House Financial Services Committee.

item.title: Euro’s Rally Faces Inflection Point as It Moves Toward $1.20
item.description: The euro’s latest rally is approaching a pivotal level that could either stall its momentum or unlock the next leg toward $1.20, a target strategists and traders have circled for months.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis

media:content.media:description: A customer pays with euro banknotes in Bremen, Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Ex-Blackstone, Tether Duo Plot $1 Billion Crypto-Reserve Push
item.description: A former Blackstone Inc. dealmaker and a co-founder of stablecoin giant Tether Holdings SA are teaming up to raise $1 billion for a listed crypto vehicle that aims to hoard a portfolio of digital assets.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Weeks, Muyao Shen

media:content.media:description: Logos for Binance Coin, top, Ether, left, and Bitcoin inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Trader Handed Suspended Sentence in UK Divorce Spat With Ex-Wife
item.description: A Russian oil trader was handed a suspended prison sentence in London, after failing to follow court orders made during a bitter divorce battle.
item.dc:creator: Hillary Boye Doku

media:content.media:description: The Royal Courts of Justice in London.

item.title: Oil Gains as US Stockpiles Drop, Trump Sticks to Iran Pressure
item.description: Oil rebounded from the biggest two-day decline since 2022 as President Donald Trump downplayed prospects of near-term sanctions relief for Iran and a government report showed a large drop in US crude stockpiles.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: The LyondellBasell Houston refinery in Houston, Texas, US, on Monday June 23, 2025. Efforts to de-escalate the Middle East conflict spurred a selloff in oil, easing concerns about inflation and driving stocks higher on hopes the Federal Reserve will have room to cut rates despite Jerome Powell's wait-and-see signals.

item.title: Municipal-Bond Market Inches Closer to $5 Trillion With a Record Quarter
item.description: Municipal-bond bankers have been extra busy this year as state and local governments rush to borrow at a record pace to fund projects.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Moran, Shruti Singh

media:content.media:description: Construction workers in San Francisco.

item.title: Czechs See Little Room for Rate Cuts as Inflation Risks Increase
item.description: The Czech central bank signaled that interest rates will remain on hold at least for several months, saying inflationary risks prevented a cut in borrowing costs at a meeting on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Krystof Chamonikolas

media:content.media:description: The Czech central bank in Prague. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: JPMorgan Traders Are Getting Shut Out of Private Credit Market
item.description: Wall Street is struggling to pry open the red-hot asset class and bring trading and transparency to the tightly held loans that have long been off-limits to them.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Schneider, Carmen Arroyo

item.title: Need to Focus on Fundamentals: Sundar
item.description: Sitara Sundar, Head of Alternative Investment Strategy at JPMorgan Private Bank, says while earnings growth will decelerate, she expects it to be in the mid-single to high-single digits. She also expects breadth to broaden and the tech sector to lead the way forward. She speaks to Bloomberg's Dani Burger on 'Bloomberg Brief.' (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Middle East War Reset Dollar’s Inverse Link to Stocks, Goldman Says
item.description: This month’s geopolitical tension focused on the Middle East is re-establishing the dollar’s traditional inverse relationship with risk assets, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson

item.title: Wall Street Pitches Sci-Fi ETFs for Robots, UFOs, Quantum Bets
item.description: In a speculative corner of the ETF world, artificial intelligence is fast becoming yesterday’s trade. Instead, the next disruptive bet on humanity’s fate is moving into the realm of science fiction: Humanoid robots, UFOs and quantum computing.
item.dc:creator: Vildana Hajric

media:content.media:description: A quantum computer system in Yorktown Heights, New York. Photographer: Angela Weiss/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Says US and Iran Will Talk Next Weel
item.description: President Donald Trump says the US will hold talks with Iran next week, and “we may sign an agreement. I don’t know.” But he adds, “I don’t think it’s necessary” in terms of getting an agreement with Tehran. Trump speaks along with Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the NATO summit. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ghana Plans First Sale of Domestic Bonds Since Debt Default
item.description: Ghana will resume domestic bond sales later in 2025 after short-term borrowing costs fell to the lowest levels in three years amid signs the nation is recovering from a recent debt crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

item.title: Middle East Oil Flows Jump as Hormuz Security Concerns Ease
item.description: Oil tanker traffic through the Strait of Hormuz rebounded as concerns about security in the vital waterway eased following the US-brokered ceasefire between Iran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Prejula Prem

media:content.media:description: Tankers are seen at the Khor Fakkan Container Terminal, the only natural deep-sea port in the region and one of the major container ports in the Sharjah Emirate, along the Strait of Hormuz, a waterway through which one-fifth of global oil output passes on June 23, 2025. (Photo by Giuseppe CACACE / AFP) (Photo by GIUSEPPE CACACE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: US New-Home Sales Drop by Most Since 2022 on Poor Affordability
item.description: US purchases of new homes fell in May by the most in almost three years as rampant sales incentives fell short of alleviating affordability constraints.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Newly built homes in Loudonville, New York.

item.title: Czech Defense Firm Increases Junk Bond Sale to $2.16 Billion
item.description: Armaments maker Czechoslovak Group AS is set to raise $2.16 billion through a junk bond sale, more than double its original intention, highlighting the relentless clamor for the defense sector among credit money managers.
item.dc:creator: Abhinav Ramnarayan, Rose Henderson

media:content.media:description: Czechoslovak Group’s Pandur 8x8 EVO wheeled armored vehicle in Brno.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/25/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Says He Thinks Israel-Iran War Is Over
item.description: President Donald Trump says the US strikes on nuclear enrichment facilities in Iran paved the way for peace during a press conference at the NATO summit at The Hague.

item.title: Deutsche PBB Returns to Junior Bonds to Replace Old Debt
item.description: German commercial property lender Deutsche Pfandbriefbank AG sold its first subordinated bond in seven years to fund the buyback of some of its old junior debt.
item.dc:creator: Tasos Vossos

media:content.media:description: The Deutsche Pfandbriefbank headquarters in Garching, Germany.

item.title: UK Electric Car Growth May Send Power Use Soaring Late at Night
item.description: Home car chargers typically power up overnight when energy is plentiful and cheap. But that’s set to change as more and more drivers go electric, upending the traditional supply-demand balance.
item.dc:creator: Eamon Farhat

media:content.media:description: A home EV charging point.

item.title: Risk-On Appetite Boosts African Bonds After Middle East Truce
item.description: African bonds are rallying as investors return to high-yield assets amid bets that the truce between Israel and Iran will hold, with lower oil prices cutting inflation expectations and boosting real rates on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Osae-Brown

media:content.media:description: Egyptian bonds led the gains in emerging markets on Wednesday. Photographer: Islam Safwat/Bloomberg

item.title: Monte Paschi Raises €500 Million as Mediobanca Deal Cleared
item.description: Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena raised €500 million ($580 million) of debt after the European Central Bank approved its takeover of Mediobanca SpA.
item.dc:creator: Ronan Martin

media:content.media:description: Monte Paschi is the world’s oldest bank.

item.title: Deutsche Boerse Said to Add Banks to $1 Billion IPO of Data Unit
item.description: Deutsche Boerse AG has added more banks to a potential $1 billion initial public offering of its governance data and analytics unit ISS Stoxx, according to people familiar with the matter, as it weighs whether to list a stake held by a private equity firm or buy it back.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath, Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro, Arno Schuetze

media:content.media:description: The trading floor at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, operated by Deutsche Boerse AG, in Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, Jan. 30, 2023. European stocks fell on Monday as investors took profit on the rally ahead of another round of rate hikes from central banks in the US, Europe and the UK amid fears of slowing economic growth.

item.title: Brazil's Green-Energy Industry Is Falling Victim to Its Own Success
item.description: Brazilian wind and solar companies have been hit by supply-chain snags, high borrowing costs and a dearth of transmission lines
item.dc:creator: Cristiane Lucchesi, Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Peter Millard

media:content.media:description: Turbines on a wind farm near Galos, Rio Grande do Norte state, Brazil, on Tuesday, Feb. 17, 2025. Latin American renewables are expected to have a healthy 2025, with BNEF seeing the region adding 26 gigawatts of clean power assets, driven by the Brazilian market.
